ARTICLE.COMMENT: A comics describing some design choices made when creating Chrome.
Some thinking about the way Chrome handles tabs.

X.T: Web Developers: Keeping Up With Google Chrome

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Web developers should use the beta channel to test the compatibility of their code with future Chrome releases.
A description of courgette, the compression mechanism used by Chrome to dramatically reduce the size of the updates.
An introduction to writing Chrome extensions.
The title says all.

X.T: Google Chrome for the holidays: Mac, Linux and extensions in beta

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The beta releases of Chrome for Mac and Linux and of the extensions.

X.T: Do You Know How Slow Your Web Page Is?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome, IE, and Firefox are implementing the Web Timing draft specification.
The user can now indicate which extensions are allowed in incognito mode.

X.T: Making Chrome more accessible with extensions

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google is releasing code to help writing accessibility extensions.
Chrome is going, from a 3 months, to a six weeks release cycle.

X.T: WebP, a new image format for the Web

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google creates a new image format… but the blog comments are quite clear: what is the need for this?
Native PDF support in Chrome.
Chrome now supports some administration features.

X.T: HTML Video Codec Support in Chrome

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google gives some news about WebM and announces that, in Chrome, the <video> tag will not support H.264.

X.T: More about the Chrome HTML Video Codec Change

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google further explains its previous announcement.
Chrome now supports background pages for applications without any visible window.

X.T: WebP in Chrome, Picasa, Gmail With a Slew of New Features and Improvements

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google is still improving its own image format (fancy upsampling, segmented adaptation…) and is claiming to gain market acceptance.

X.T: New developer tools experimental APIs for Chrome extensions

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An API extending developer tools.
A page can be prefetched while the user types its URL. Downloaded executable files are analyzed to check if they are known to be malicious.
Marketting bullshit: Chromebook is a success in US schools.

X.T: Enhancing The Developer and End-User Experience on ChromeVox

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The intern in charge of cleaning up ChromeVox code gives some (very well known) advice on having clean code. Then, the intern who performed ChromeVox integration in several Google products describes the API he created. At last, yet another intern describes the intelligent focus management.

X.T: Lossless and Transparency Modes in WebP

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: 10 Chrome tricks to improve your browsing experience
X.ST: No hacks, no registry tweaks, no add-ons: Just an arsenal of built-in tricks to make Chrome do your bidding.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: How to use 'Pin Tab' to organize your work in Google Chrome
X.ST: Google Chrome's "Pin Tab" feature is an often-overlooked option that can help power users organize their work in the browser and manage tab creep.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.
Chrome is dropping support of showModalDialog.

X.T: Responsive Web Design with DevTools' Device Mode

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome now includes some features to emulate mobiles, including their bandwidth and ping time.

X.T: New JavaScript techniques for rapid page loads

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Parallel parsing of the JavaScript and caching the compiled code.
Google stops supporting Chrome on Vista and XP.
Avoiding page jumps while offscreen content is loaded.
JavaScript continues to catch up on regular expression capabilities compared to other languages.

X.T: Run multiple versions of Chrome side-by-side

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome, Chrome Beta, and Chrome Dev can now be installed side by side.
The title says all.
JavaScript modules, Web Share API, and WebUSB API.
A proposal for a new API for creating a floating video window over other windows.
An API to trigger the native Android share dialog.
A new API (Generic Sensor API) is added to access the accelerometer and gyroscope data.

X.T: Chrome 62 Beta: Network Quality Estimator API, OpenType variable fonts, and media capture from DOM elements

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.
The title says all.
Same content as for the 62 beta version.
Yet another way to integrate native and web applications.

X.T: Expanding user protections on the web

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome includes some new mechanisms to detect and block unwanted navigation to a new page.

X.T: Reducing Chrome crashes caused by third-party software

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome will block most code injections performed on it.
Dynamic module imports, async iterators and generators, defining over-scroll behavior, change in the dialogs for permission requests.
A short description of AudioWorkletProcessor and AudioWorkletNode.
Chrome 64 adds the <link rel="modulepreload"> syntax for preloading modules.
Google wants us to test the impact of hardware noise suppression on the sound quality of WebRTC.
A presentation of the Device Memory API and several ways to use it.

X.T: Further protecting users from deceptive or confusing inline installation

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google is using machine learning to detect deceptive extension installations.
A short description of the CSS Paint API.

X.T: The browser for a web worth protecting

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome will block adds not respecting the Better Ads Standards.

X.T: Under the hood: How Chrome's ad filtering works

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some informations on how ads will be blocked and how site owners can handle this.
The CSS Paint API, the Server Timing API, and the display: contents CSS property.

X.T: Credential Management API Feature Detection Check-up

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The way to perform feature detection for the Credential Management API must be updated to handle the PublicKeyCredential added by WebAuthn.
The text methods of the Asynchronous Clipboard API are now supported by Chrome.
Cryptocurrency mining extensions will be removed from Chrome Web Store.
Google experiments with using MacOS echo cancellation and wants people to test it for them.

X.T: Working with the new CSS Typed Object Model

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome 66 supports the CSS Typed Object Model, an object-oriented API to manipulate the CSS.

X.T: Present web pages to secondary attached displays

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome 66 supports the Presentation API so an application can drive a secondary display.
The CSS Typed Model Object, the Asynchronous Clipboard API, and streamlined rendering of images in canvases.
The title says all.

X.T: Chrome 67 Beta: WebXR Origin Trial, Generic Sensors

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Generic Sensor API is now supported and a trial is started for WebXR Device API.
Google still tries to get an adequate algorithm for accepting or ignoring autoplay.

X.T: Progressive Web Apps on the Desktop

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The fact that PWAs are now supported on ChromeOS and some advice on designing a PWA so it is properly displayed on a desktop.
Google proposes a new metric, First Input Delay: its definition, the difference with Time To Interactive and how to collect it.
A short introduction to the WebXR Device API.
Desktop PWAs, Generic Sensor API, BigIntand WebAuthn.

X.T: Changes to Add to Home Screen Behavior

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all, yet another modification to Add to Home Screen and this will change again in the future.
By default, the HTTP cache will be bypassed when fetching the service worker script.

X.T: Bring your payment method to the web with the Payment Handler API

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of the Payment Handler API.

X.T: Chrome 68 Beta: add to home screen, payment handler, page lifecycle

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Changed add to home screen behavior, Payment Handler API, some redirections now require a user gesture, Page Lifecycle API, fetching a service worker script bypasses the cache…
Extension inline installation will be removed in a few months.
A presentation of the WebXR Hit Test API.

X.T: Chacmool: Augmented reality in Chrome Canary

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Presentation of an AR demo and some advice for building AR applications.
The same than 3 months ago with MacOS: Google asks people to test Windows native noise cancellation, explaining that they already know it does work properly.

X.T: Experimenting with First Input Delay in the Chrome UX Report

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome UX now report the First Input Delay (the duration between the user intercation and the Browser responding to it).
A presentation of Feature Policy: Feature-Policy HTTP header, iframe's allow attribute, and JavaScript API.
A presentation of the Page Lifecycle API and how to properly use it.

Some changes in Add to Home and in the Payment Handler API, addition of the ScreenPage Lifecycle API, redirecting from an iframe requires a user gesture, HTTP cache is bypassed when upgrading a service worker
The basic-card payment method is replaced by the Google Pay API.
An explanation of how the NoState Prefetch works.

X.T: Chrome 69 Beta: CSS tricks, and more

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome 69 Beta contains many changes: CSS new features, OffscreenCanvas, new or improved APIs, mid-ligature text selection…
The ReportingObserver API can be used to programmatically detect the deprecation and intervention reports generated by Chrome.

X.T: Well-Controlled Scrolling with CSS Scroll Snap

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of the new version of CSS Scroll Snap and its current implementation status in Chrome.
Support of AV1 codec, querying the supported EME encryption schemes, the new HDCP Policy Check API…

X.T: OffscreenCanvas — Speed up Your Canvas Operations with a Web Worker

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short presentation of OffscreenCanvas.
CSS Scroll Snap, managing display on screens with notches, and the Web Locks API.
A summary of the history of Chrome.
A Report-To HTTP Header defines to which endpoint the errors of each type should be reported.

X.T: How we designed Chrome 10 years ago

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The four core principles: simplicity, speed, security, and stability.
Some advice to not use cookies and a description of the Cookie Store API.

X.T: Chrome 70 beta: shape detection, web authentication, and more

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Shape Detection API (Face Detection API, Barcode Detection API and Text Detection API) has been added and numerous small changes have been made.
Switching the codec and bytestream format, support of Opus in MP4, and protected content playback now allowed by default.

X.T: Product updates based on your feedback

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google is making profile management even more unclear: when you sign into any Google website, you'll also be signed into Chrome with the same account.
Some security improvements for extensions: host permissions, code obfuscation is now disallowed, two steps verification for store developers, manifest V3.
Yet another animation API: AnimationWorklet.
Desktop Progressive Web Apps now available on Windows, Public Key Credentials, and Web Worker names.

X.T: Tweaks to cache.addAll() and importScripts() coming in Chrome 71

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Two non upward compatible changes: importScripts() cannot be called asynchronously and cache.addAll() rejects duplicated URLs.
An introduction to the Picture-in-Picture Web API.

X.T: Chrome 71 Beta: relative time formats and more

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Intl.RelativeTimeFormat API and numerous small changes.
The title says all.
An origin trial for Signed HTTP Exchange, a mechanism to publish a Web Package from a site other that its origin, is started.

X.T: Further protections from harmful ad experiences on the web

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google creates a black list of sites with abusive ads, Chrome will remove all ads on these ones.

X.T: Notifying users of unclear subscription pages

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google wants to fight hidden billing, but I do not understand how Chrome can automatically detect that.

X.T: Web Audio, Autoplay Policy and Games

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The rules for allowing autoplay have been slightly changed after having received some feedback from the Web developers.
Intl.RelativeTimeFormat(), specifying underline location for vertical text and speech synthesis now requires user activation.
A presentation of the Background Fetch API.

X.T: Registering as a Share Target with the Web Share Target API

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An explanation on how to use the Web Share Target API which is available in Chrome 71.
A description of the simple Badging API and a call for comments.
V8 starts to support public/private (possibly static) fields and private static methods.

X.T: I’m Awake! Stay Awake with the WakeLock API

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the Wake Lock API (to prevent the device from going to sleep or from locking the screen) and a call for comments.
Intl.ListFormat has been added to format lists.

X.T: Chrome 72 Beta: Public class fields, user activation and more

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Public class fields, User Activation Query API, Intl.ListFormat()…

X.T: Check If Your Native App Is Installed With getInstalledRelatedApps

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the getInstalledRelatedApps API (to list related apps) and a call for comments

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome 72 has new version of User Activation.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: What should be the limitations imposed to local pages?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The rational for Chrome Password Manager implementation.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short summary of the security analysis for extensions.

X.T: Security in Depth: New Security Features

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some new security features have been integrated in Chrome 4: the Strict-Transport-Security header, the postMessage API, the Origin header, the X-Frame-Options header, and protection against reflective XSS.
Chrome now supports iframe's sandbox attribute.
Chrome checks downloaded files against the Safe Browsing blacklist.
A list of security improvements in Chrome 11, 12 and 13: strong random numbers, HSTS, blocked HTTP basic auth for sub-resource loads…

A description of some security features of Chromebooks: a read-only firmware check the signature of the BIOS and the OS, auto-updates (who is not doing this?), reinstall the OS from an USB storage (same comment)…
Chrome 18 will have Content Security Policy enabled by default.
A description of ClusterFuzz, an infrastructure running 50.000.000 tests per day on the latest stable build and analyzing the crashes.
An impressive use of several Chrome bugs to get full privileges on the user's machine (and win 60000$).
A similar story.
Certificates using SHA-1 and expiring after 2017-01-01 will be considered insecure.

X.T: Say “yes” to HTTPS: Chrome secures the web, one site at a time

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome's security messages result into more and more sites using HTTPS.
Some advice on how site owners can limit Meltdown/Spectre attacks and what the Chrome team is doing on its side.

X.T: A secure web is here to stay

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome 68 will report HTTP sites as insecure.
A short presentation of WebAuthn.
Once again, the same message about reporting HTTP sites as insecure, but the target is now Chrome 70.
A description of the API encapsulating WebKit in Chromium.
A high level overview of the data structures and methods implemented in WebKit..
A description of the Webkit layout tests as they are implemented in Chromium's testing infrastructure.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A quick presentation of WebKit, its performance tests, and some performance improvements made in it.

PNaCl is dead.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Debugging a Chrome tab in another Chrome instance.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some tools to analyze the memory usage.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some tips and tricks about some of the Dev Tools.
Mostly Chrome and few Firefox/Opera commands to output some information in the console.

X.T: Look What You Made Me Do, Chrome
X.ST: How to use Chrome Developer Tools to get tickets to Taylor Swift’s next concert

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using Chrome to understand the requests of a site and hack this one.

X.T: Using DevTools Features Without Opening DevTools

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using Puppeteer to access a DevTools tool without opening DevTools.

X.T: Art of debugging with Chrome DevTools

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some Chrome DevTools tips and tricks.
The history of Chrome DevTools.
Edits of CSS and JavaScript can be saved locally, some tools to inspect accessibility, some new Lighthouse checks, improved code stepping.

Showing the real initiator of a network request rather that the API wrapping the call, the same when setting breakpoints, minified resources are prettified, preview of the HTML payload of a request, improved local overrides, and auto-adjust zoom in Device Mode.
Search across all network headers and responses, search UI improvements, copy as fetch, audit improvements, stop current JavaScript call, the Performance tabs now contains User Timing measures…
Improved console (expression result preview, argument tooltip, autocomplete on function results, ES2017), Lighthouse 3.0, BigInt and Add property path to watch.
Continuous display of the value of a pinned expression, highlight of the DOM element which is the result of an eager evaluation, better 3G emulation…
Hovering over a Live Expression highlights the DOM node, initiator and priority information is stored in HAR files, breakpoints for Picture-in-Picture events…
Performance metrics in the timeline, text nodes are highlighted in the viewport, generating a JavaScript expression which is the path of a shadow node, Lighthouse upgraded to 3.2.

Logpoint (quick way to log the value of an expression in the console), the node inspection tooltip nows contains style properties, export of code coverage data, keyboard navigation of the console, contrast guidelines in the Color Picker, saving custom geolocation overrides…
